name: Maximum Depth of Binary Tree

title: Maximum Depth of Binary Tree
content:
Given the root of a binary tree, return its maximum depth.

A binary tree's maximum depth is the number of nodes along the longest path from the root node down to the farthest leaf node.

 

Example 1:

Input: root = [3,9,20,null,null,15,7]
Output: 3

Example 2:

Input: root = [1,null,2]
Output: 2

 

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the tree is in the range [0, 104].
  • -100 <= Node.val <= 100

discussion_posts.name: atebitbyte
discussion_posts.content: This problem's solution set is inaccurate. It's counting the number of nodes from root to furthest leaf, when it should be counting the number of edges (it's using an incorrect definition of tree depth/height). Please correct this.

discussion_posts.name: huda24
discussion_posts.content: SOLVED THIS ONE USING RECURSION MYSELF LESGOOOOO

discussion_posts.name: shivanikohlii
discussion_posts.content: From my understanding of depth of tree, it is supposed to be the number of edges from the root to the lowest leaf, explained in [this post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2603692/what-is-the-difference-between-tree-depth-and-heightp://). In the example in the description shouldn\'t the depth be 2?
